question: What natural source of extreme heat can transform limestone into marble?

content.source_1: When magma intrudes the crust, it transfers substantial heat to the surrounding country rock; this “baking” can metamorphose nearby rock without melting it (contact metamorphism).
content.source_2: Limestone, a sedimentary rock composed mostly of calcite, recrystallizes into marble when it undergoes metamorphism, producing an interlocking mosaic of calcite crystals.
content.source_3: Raising a rock’s temperature while it remains solid (often with some pressure) can transform it into a metamorphic rock; metamorphism is a solid-state process.
content.source_4: Mafic magmas are typically about 1100–1200°C; their heat can raise adjacent country rock to very high temperatures, approaching or exceeding conditions where carbonate rocks decarbonate. Calcite in limestone thermally decomposes to CaO + CO2 at roughly 825–900°C when CO2 pressure is low.
content.source_5: If a rock melts, it becomes magma; upon cooling and solidifying, it forms an igneous rock, not a metamorphic rock.
content.source_6: Many marbles form during regional metamorphism caused by deep burial: high pressure and geothermal heating (away from direct magma contact) drive solid-state recrystallization of limestone into marble.
